newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: Seoul stocks close higher despite Hanbo crisis.
newsitem.headline: Seoul stocks close higher despite Hanbo crisis.

text.p: South Korean stocks closed higher on Saturday on late bargain hunting as investors believed government steps would limit the impact from the financial failure of Hanbo Steel, brokers said.
They said expectations of an expansion of the foreign stock ownership limit also helped buying.
The composite index ended 5.55 points higher at 685.11.
"The Hanbo issue will linger for the time being. But it seems to be shadowed by hopes of fund inflows from foreigners," said Chang Keun-ho, a broker at Daishin Securities.
The government has said the ceiling for foreign investment would be raised to 23 percent this year from 20 percent.
"The government's moves to minimise the adverse effect of Hanbo failure appear to have improved sentiment," said Kim Heung-shik of Hyundai Securities.
The Bank of Korea said it pumped in one trillion won into commercial banks to ease a credit squeeze caused by Hanbo's crisis.
The Finance Ministry said on Friday the central bank would also provide emergency operating funds to Hanbo's suppliers and subcontractors.
Hanbo Steel defauled on payments of more than five billion won worth of promissory notes on Thursday.
Half-day trade volume totalled 22.4 million shares, compared with 35.49 million on Friday.
Advancers outpaced retreaters 581 to 191 with 85 unchanged.
